description:
Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus (OHFV) is a zoonotic virus that belongs to the genus Flavivirus, family Flaviviridae. It is primarily transmitted to humans through the bite of infected ticks, particularly the Dermacentor tick species.

OHFV is an enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. The virus primarily infects cells in the reticuloendothelial system, causing damage to the endothelial cells and leading to increased vascular permeability and hemorrhagic manifestations.

The clinical symptoms of Omsk hemorrhagic fever (OHF) include sudden onset of fever, headache, muscle pain, gastrointestinal symptoms, and progressive hemorrhagic manifestations, such as nose bleeds, gum bleeding, and skin rashes. In severe cases, the disease can lead to multi-organ failure and high mortality rates.

OHFV is primarily found in Siberia, Russia, and parts of Central Asia. The virus is maintained in nature through a tick-rodent-tick transmission cycle, with small rodents serving as the natural reservoir hosts.

Effective treatment for OHF is limited, and prevention primarily relies on personal protective measures, such as avoiding tick-infested areas, using insect repellents, and proper tick removal. Vaccination is not widely available, and research is ongoing to develop effective countermeasures against this potentially deadly viral infection.
